qa_pairs.question: What are the three key limitations on the Section 179 deduction, and how do they interact with a taxpayer's ability to deduct the full cost of eligible property in a given year?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The three key limitations on the Section 179 deduction are a dollar limitation, a threshold for total property placed in service, and a limit tied to the taxpayer's active business income. These limitations interact by restricting the full cost deduction of eligible property based on financial thresholds and taxable income. <cite>[S11][S12][S13][S14][S15][S16]</cite></statement> <statement>The first limitation is a dollar cap: for 2020, the maximum deduction is $1,040,000, as specified under Section 179(b)(1). This cap directly restricts the amount a taxpayer can deduct in a single year. <cite>[S12][S13]</cite></statement> <statement>The second limitation reduces the deduction if the taxpayer places more than $2,000,000 in Section 179 property into service during the year. The deduction is reduced dollar-for-dollar by the amount exceeding the $2,500,000 threshold. <cite>[S14]</cite></statement> <statement>The third limitation ensures the deduction does not exceed the taxpayer's aggregate income from active business operations. For example, if a taxpayer’s business income is $72,500, the deduction cannot exceed that amount, though unused portions may be carried forward. <cite>[S15][S16]</cite></statement> <statement>These limitations interact by creating layered restrictions: the dollar cap sets an initial limit, the property threshold adjusts it based on total investments, and the income limit ensures deductions align with the taxpayer’s taxable earnings. <cite>[S11][S12][S13][S14][S15][S16]</cite></statement>

# Section 179 depreciation deduction



**Section 179** of the United States Internal Revenue Code (26 U.S.C. [S2] § 179), allows a taxpayer to elect to deduct the cost of certain types of property on their income taxes as an expense, rather than requiring the cost of the property to be capitalized and depreciated. [S3] This property is generally limited to tangible, depreciable, personal property which is acquired by purchase for use in the active conduct of a trade or business. [S4] Buildings were not eligible for section 179 deductions prior to the passage of the Small Business Jobs Act of 2010; however, qualified real property may be deducted now. [S5] Depreciable property that is not eligible for a section 179 deduction is still deductible over a number of years through MACRS depreciation according to sections 167 and 168. [S6] The 179 election is optional, and the eligible property may be depreciated according to sections 167 and 168 if preferable for tax reasons. [S7] Further, the 179 election may be made only for the year the equipment is placed in use and is waived if not taken for that year. [S8] However, if the election is made, it is irrevocable unless special permission is given. [S9] For regular depreciation deductions in the United States, see MACRS. [S10] ## Limitations

The section 179 election is subject to three important limitations. [S11] First, there is a dollar limitation. [S12] Under section 179(b)(1), the maximum deduction a taxpayer may take in a year is $1,040,000 for tax year 2020. [S13] Second, if a taxpayer places more than $2,000,000 worth of section 179 property into service during a single taxable year, the § 179 deduction is reduced, dollar for dollar, by the amount exceeding the $2,500,000 threshold, again as of January 1, 2018. [S14] Finally, section 179(b)(3) provides that a taxpayer's § 179 deduction for any taxable year may not exceed the taxpayer's aggregate income from the active conduct of trade or business by the taxpayer for that year. [S15] If, for example, the taxpayer's net trade or business income from active conduct of trade or business was $72,500 in 2006, then the taxpayer's § 179 deduction cannot exceed $72,500 for 2006. [S16] However, the § 179 deduction not allowed for any year because of this limitation can be carried over to the next year. [S17] ## Large vehicles

Up to $25,500 of the cost of vehicles rated at more than 6,000 pounds gross vehicle weight and not more than 14,000 pounds gross vehicle weight (like RV) can be deducted using a section 179 deduction. [S18] The limitation on sport utility vehicles does not impact larger commercial vehicles, commuter vans, or buses.

[S1] Section 179 depreciation deduction


# Section 179 depreciation deduction



**Section 179** of the United States Internal Revenue Code (26 U.S.C. [S2] § 179), allows a taxpayer to elect to deduct the cost of certain types of property on their income taxes as an expense, rather than requiring the cost of the property to be capitalized and depreciated. [S3] This property is generally limited to tangible, depreciable, personal property which is acquired by purchase for use in the active conduct of a trade or business. [S4] Buildings were not eligible for section 179 deductions prior to the passage of the Small Business Jobs Act of 2010; however, qualified real property may be deducted now. [S5] Depreciable property that is not eligible for a section 179 deduction is still deductible over a number of years through MACRS depreciation according to sections 167 and 168. [S6] The 179 election is optional, and the eligible property may be depreciated according to sections 167 and 168 if preferable for tax reasons. [S7] Further, the 179 election may be made only for the year the equipment is placed in use and is waived if not taken for that year. [S8] However, if the election is made, it is irrevocable unless special permission is given. [S9] For regular depreciation deductions in the United States, see MACRS. [S10] ## Limitations

The section 179 election is subject to three important limitations. [S11] First, there is a dollar limitation. [S12] Under section 179(b)(1), the maximum deduction a taxpayer may take in a year is $1,040,000 for tax year 2020. [S13] Second, if a taxpayer places more than $2,000,000 worth of section 179 property into service during a single taxable year, the § 179 deduction is reduced, dollar for dollar, by the amount exceeding the $2,500,000 threshold, again as of January 1, 2018. [S14] Finally, section 179(b)(3) provides that a taxpayer's § 179 deduction for any taxable year may not exceed the taxpayer's aggregate income from the active conduct of trade or business by the taxpayer for that year. [S15] If, for example, the taxpayer's net trade or business income from active conduct of trade or business was $72,500 in 2006, then the taxpayer's § 179 deduction cannot exceed $72,500 for 2006. [S16] However, the § 179 deduction not allowed for any year because of this limitation can be carried over to the next year. [S17] ## Large vehicles

Up to $25,500 of the cost of vehicles rated at more than 6,000 pounds gross vehicle weight and not more than 14,000 pounds gross vehicle weight (like RV) can be deducted using a section 179 deduction. [S18] The limitation on sport utility vehicles does not impact larger commercial vehicles, commuter vans, or buses.
